perturbation.original_text:
2.17.1Datec will provide a central point for the generation of new user logons and passwords as agreed with the BSP.

2.17.2Datec will reset passwords and perform logon ID administration in accordance with BSP's security guidelines.

2.17.3User logon and password administration include providing access and administering passwords for firewalls and internet requirements.
perturbation.changed_text:
2.17.1 Datec will only provide a central point for the generation of new user logons and passwords if Datec has the resources and capabilities to do so.

2.17.2 Datec may reset passwords and perform logon ID administration at its own discretion.

2.17.3 User logon and password administration may not include providing access and administering passwords for firewalls and internet requirements.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that Datec 'will' provide services for user logon and password administration. The modified text introduces uncertainty by saying Datec 'will only provide', 'may reset', and 'may not include' these services. This contradiction creates confusion about Datec's obligations.

perturbation.original_text:
14.3 Termination By BSP For Convenience

The BSP may terminate the whole or any part of this agreement for convenience at any time by giving Datec at least 6 months prior written notice.

14.4 Termination By Datec For Convenience

Datec may terminate the whole or any part of this agreement for convenience at any time by giving the BSP at least 6 months prior written notice.
perturbation.changed_text:
14.3 Termination By BSP For Convenience

The BSP may terminate the whole or any part of this agreement for convenience at any time by giving Datec at least 6 months prior written notice.

14.4 Termination By Datec For Convenience

Datec may terminate the whole or any part of this agreement for convenience only with the explicit written consent of BSP and giving the BSP at least 12 months prior written notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows both BSP and Datec to terminate the agreement for convenience with 6 months' notice. The modified text makes it significantly harder for Datec to terminate by requiring BSP's consent and doubling the notice period, which contradicts the original reciprocal right.

perturbation.original_text:
8.5 Rebates

1.  Should Datec not achieve the agreed Service Levels contained in the Service Level Agreement as detailed in Schedule B, a monthly rebate will be applied as per the Rebate Table in Pricing Schedule C,

2.  Rebates will apply to Severity Levels One (1) and Two (2) during the agreed business hours detailed in Schedule B.

3.  The maximum rebate in any given month will be 50% of the monthly base fee. The rebate calculation will be completed before the 15th Day of the following month for the preceding month together with supporting monthly reports and provided to the BSP.

4.  For the purposes of determining SLA achievement the "Time to Respond" measurement will be used.
perturbation.changed_text:
8.5 Rebates

1.  Rebates for Datec's failure to achieve the agreed Service Levels are at the sole discretion of BSP and may not always be applied.

2.  Whether or not rebates apply to Severity Levels One (1) and Two (2) during the agreed business hours is subject to a separate agreement between BSP and Datec on a monthly basis.

3.  The maximum potential rebate in any given month is 50% of the monthly base fee; however, the actual rebate amount, if any, is determined by BSP's subjective assessment of Datec's performance.

4.  For the purposes of determining potential SLA achievement, the "Time to Respond" measurement may be considered but is not the only factor.
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly states that rebates 'will' be applied if service levels are not met. The modified text removes this certainty by stating that rebates are 'at the sole discretion of BSP', 'subject to a separate agreement', and dependent on BSP's 'subjective assessment'. This creates a contradiction as the original implies an objective, contractual obligation to provide rebates, while the modified version makes it discretionary.
